title: R43557
content: The report provides an overview of FY2015 legislative branch appropriations, detailing actions such as the submission of requests, hearings, markups, and the passage of H.R. 4487. It also covers the enactment of various appropriations acts and funding levels for FY2014 and FY2015. The FY2015 U.S. Budget submitted on March 4, 2014, includes a request for $4.471 billion in new budget authority for legislative branch activities. Hearings of the legislative branch subcommittees in 2014 were held, and the House subcommittee marked up the FY2015 bill on April 4, 2014. The full House Appropriations Committee also held a markup of the bill on April 9, 2014. Representative Moran proposed the creation of an optional housing stipend of $25 per day for Members. The House of Representatives considered H.R. 4487 on May 1, 2014, with various amendments proposed. Representative Nugent's amendment to prohibit funding for vehicle leasing through the Member Representational Allowance failed. Representative Speier's amendment to allocate $500,000 for sexual harassment training was approved. Representative Gosar's amendment to reduce Botanic Garden funding to FY2014 levels and transfer funds was passed. Representative Broun's amendment to cut Capitol Visitor Center funding by $243,000 was also approved. The House of Representatives considered various amendments to H.R. 4487 on May 1, 2014. Amendments included reducing funding for the Capitol Visitor Center, defunding the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund, prohibiting printed copies of House documents, and reinstating the Office of Technology Assessment. H.R. 4487, as amended, was passed by the House with a vote of 402-14. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered the bill on June 19, 2014, ordering it reported favorably with an amendment in the nature of a substitute. No further action was taken on H.R. 4487. The enactment of two continuing appropriations resolutions provided funding for the legislative branch until the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015. The FY2015 act provides $4.3 billion for legislative branch operations, an increase of 1.0% from FY2014. A funding gap in FY2014 resulted in a partial government shutdown for 16 days, which was terminated by a CR. The Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 provided $4.3 billion for legislative branch operations, an increase of 1.0% from FY2014. The act funded legislative branch accounts at the FY2012 enacted level with some exceptions and less across-the-board rescissions required by Section 3004 of a previous law. Sequestration reductions implemented on March 1 reduced most legislative branch accounts by 5.0%. Subsequent to the enactment of the previous law, additional rescissions of 0.032% of security budget authority and 0.2% of nonsecurity budget authority were required. In FY2012, $4.307 billion was provided for the legislative branch, a decrease from previous years. The budget remains below the FY2004 level in constant dollars. The Senate requested a 5.6% increase for FY2015. The Senate requested a $907.2 million budget for FY2015, a 5.6% increase from FY2014. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $865.9 million, a 0.8% increase. The FY2015 act provided $864.3 million. The inquiries and investigations account received $134.0 million, with a 1.0% increase from FY2014. The Committee on Appropriations account received $14.94 million, the same as FY2014. The Senators' Official Personnel and Office Expense Account (SOPOEA) provided funds for each Senator's office expenses. The Senate and House requested different budget amounts for FY2015, with the Senate requesting $429.7 million and the House requesting $1.20 billion. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $390.0 million, while the House-passed bill and FY2015 act provided $1.18 billion. The House committees' funding for personnel and nonpersonnel expenses remained at $123.9 million, the same level as FY2014. The House requested $23.7 million for the Committee on Appropriations, while the Members' Representational Allowance was set at $565.4 million for FY2015. The U.S. Capitol Police requested $355.7 million, an increase of 5.1% from the previous year. The House-passed bill provided $348.0 million for the police. The U.S. Capitol Police requested $291.4 million for salaries, an increase of 4.4% from the previous year. The general expenses account includes funds for various expenses such as vehicles, security equipment, training programs, and other administrative support. The House-passed bill provided $286.5 million for salaries, while the Senate-reported bill recommended $284.6 million. The Capitol Police requested increased funding for general expenses and Capitol Police buildings and grounds in FY2015. The House-passed bill and Senate Appropriations Committee recommended varying levels of funding, with discussions on training requests, radio modernization, incidents involving USCP, and discrimination complaints. The Senate subcommittee discussed incidents involving USCP and funding levels for the Office of Compliance in a hearing on March 25, 2014. The Office of Compliance requested $4.02 million for FY2015, with the House Appropriations Committee recommending $3.96 million. The House-passed bill included $4.5 million, with funds for sexual harassment training. The Senate-reported bill allocated $3.96 million for FY2015. The Senate-reported version of H.R. 4487 included language authorizing the Office of Compliance to send notifications electronically. CBO requested $46.1 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $45.7 million. Discussions at hearings included CBO projections and methodologies. Two administrative provisions were requested by CBO for FY2015 funds. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for maintaining and operating the U.S. Capitol Complex, including various buildings and grounds. The Architect requested $676.6 million for FY2015, an increase of 12.4% from the previous year. The Architect of the Capitol requested $676.6 million for FY2015, an increase of 12.4% from FY2014. The House-passed bill would have provided $484.9 million, including amendments to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden and offset training costs. The Senate-reported bill would have provided $600.0 million. The FY2015 act ultimately provided $600.2 million (-0.3%). Administrative provisions in the House-passed and Senate-reported versions of H.R. 4487 were related to building façades and educational outreach efforts. The FY2015 act included provisions related to educational outreach efforts of the U.S. Botanic Garden and funding for Capitol Dome rehabilitation. The Library of Congress serves as both Congress's library and the national library, with services including acquisition, maintenance, preservation of a collection, administration of copyright laws, and a program for the blind and physically handicapped. The Library of Congress provides reading material to the blind and physically handicapped, legal research, and law-related services to Congress. The FY2015 budget requested $593.1 million, with the final act providing $590.9 million. Salaries and expenses saw an increase from $405.7 million in FY2014 to $414.5 million in FY2015. The Library of Congress budget for FY2015 included funding for the Copyright Office, Congressional Research Service, and Books for the Blind and Physically Handicapped. The House-passed bill and Senate-reported levels varied for each department, with slight increases in funding compared to the previous year. The Library of Congress budget for FY2015 included funds for the Architect's budget, Library buildings and grounds, and the Copyright Office. The requested amount was $62.8 million, with the House-passed bill proposing $41.7 million and the Senate-reported bill proposing $47.6 million. Discussions in hearings focused on issues in the Copyright Office, management and planning within the Library, plans for the Twitter archive, and book preservation. GPO requested $128.9 million for FY2015, an 8.1% increase from the previous year. The Government Publishing Office (GPO) requested $128.9 million for FY2015, an 8.1% increase from the previous year. The House-passed bill proposed $122.6 million, the Senate-reported bill proposed $122.1 million, and the enacted bill provided $119.99 million. GPO's budget authority is divided into three accounts, with congressional publishing receiving $85.4 million, Public Information Programs of the Superintendent of Documents receiving $32.2 million, and the Government Publishing Office Business Operations Revolving Fund. The FY2015 budget for the Government Publishing Office (GPO) was $31.5 million, the same as FY2014. The GPO Business Operations Revolving fund received $8.8 million, an increase of $693,000. The Senate-reported bill included renaming GPO to Government Publishing Office and making staff references gender-neutral. The House subcommittee discussed GPO's budget request in March 2014. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) requested $525.1 million for FY2015, an increase of 3.9% from the previous year. The FY2015 act provided $522.0 million, with three administrative provisions requested by GAO. These provisions included amending reviews and reports required by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, authorizing personnel detail from other branches or agencies, and establishing a Center for Audit Excellence on a fee-based basis. The House and Senate passed H.R. 4487, which included language establishing the Center for Audit Excellence. Discussions in House and Senate subcommittees focused on GAO requests, savings from recommendations, and plans for the Center. The Open World Leadership Center supports democratic changes in other countries by inviting their leaders to observe democracy and free enterprise in the United States. The Open World Leadership Center was established in 1988 to promote public service by congressional staff. In FY2015, it requested $8.0 million, but the House-passed bill proposed $3.42 million (-43.0%) due to the high percentage of Russian participants. The Senate-reported bill suggested $5.7 million, a decrease of $300,000 (-5.0%) from FY2014. The Center also requested $430,000 for FY2015, the same as the previous year. The Stennis Center received $430,000 in FY2013, with the Senate-reported bill supporting this funding level. However, the House-passed bill did not provide funding, citing the lack of a detailed budget justification. The Center was established in 1988 with an initial appropriation of $7.5 million, which was later transferred to the John C. Stennis Trust Fund. The Stennis Center has $15 million invested with the U.S. Treasury, generating $300,000 at a 2 percent return for annual operations. The Committee has provided zero funding for the Center due to reduced funding within the Legislative Branch. Any future budget requests must include a detailed justification. Funding for the Center has varied in previous fiscal years. The House-passed and Senate-reported versions of H.R. 4487 included provisions freezing pay for Members of Congress in 2015. Salaries for Members of Congress are not funded or increased in any appropriations bill. Provisions to prohibit automatic adjustments have been discussed in other bills and could be included in future legislation. The Senate-reported bill included restrictions on bonus awards to contractors for projects behind schedule or over budget. P.L. 113-235 prohibits funds for painting portraits of federal government officials. Tables provide funding levels for legislative branch entities. Selected websites offer information on FY2015 legislative branch appropriations. The curr_chunk provides links to various government websites related to appropriations, including the Committee on Appropriations, Congressional Budget Office, Government Accountability Office, and Office of Management and Budget.
